title: Lingering in Eregion
description: As I have written here probably too many times at this point, my current run at Lord of the Rings Online is not focused on being completionist.  I do not need to do all the things.  I have even decided to be somewhat lax on the epic quest line.  The goal is to get to […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: As I have written here probably too many times at this point, my current run at Lord of the Rings Online is not focused on being completionist. I do not need to do all the things. I have even dec…
text: As I have written here probably too many times at this point, my current run at Lord of the Rings Online is not focused on being completionist.  I do not need to do all the things.  I have even decided to be somewhat lax on the epic quest line.  The goal is to get to Mordor. And then I hit Eregion, which is not a zone I have an affinity for generally… at least not at the level of Evendim or the Lone Lands.  It is a place… even a pretty place at times… but it isn’t exactly a distinctive place.  As a zone injected into the game to be the path between the original content and the first expansion, it can feel more than a little like past zones. Riding across Eregion At least there are not any bears there.  Birds, boars, wolves, lizards, half-orcs, various hillmen, and the Angmar choral society… and Redhorn goats, so many Redhorn goats… but bears… none that I have seen.  And, of course, the ruins of a past age. Ruins, ruins, everywhere… also tents, because the half orcs have to sleep somewhere… Everybody seems to be just camped out in one ruin or another.  That aligns, somewhat, with the books, the place being desolate and lacking any permanent habitation.  Of course, what doesn’t align with the books is you inability to toss a hobbit in any direction without them landing on the above list of wildlife. There is even yet another escort quest where you shepherd Anurandir out of a heavily populated orc camp… which is, of course, based in some more ruins. It is hardly a zone if there isn’t at least one quest like this… I will say that at least Anurandir doesn’t mess about looking for his stick or his dad’s war surplus bayonet.  He heads on out of the area via the shortest possible path. Anyway, despite all of that once I had hit level 50 and had my epic weapons… I kept on hanging around the place. Part of it is that it is one of the zones where you do cross paths… if not directly, at least incidentally… with the fellowship on their journey eastward…. through the medium of discarded hobbit items. It is a wonder Strider didn’t stuff them all in a sack… You spend time trying to figure out where the fellowship went, what they had for lunch, and who left behind the latest bit of hobbit memorabilia. Seriously, I saw a crying half-orc on the side of the road by this So you follow the path of the fellowship through Hollin, up to the Redhorn Gate, then back around towards Moria… though, because the landscape must necessarily be condensed to a small enough area that it is easily traversable by players… the way the road from Buckland to Bree isn’t actually 75 miles in the game… makes it feel a bit like the fellowship was a an indolent pack of layabouts that could only manage half a mile at a time before collapsing in exhaustion.  I think you can literally see one of the camping spots from the next. Eregion has a couple of other benefits.  It is, like some of my other favored zones, fairly quest rich in the traditional “vacuum up everything at the quest hub and go wild” sort of way.  I appreciate being able to go into the field to get a lot done in one pass. Also, in the back half of the zone you end up collecting the next tier of resources. Heavy, just how I like em I am not crafting… but I am harvesting.  At least up until my transferred crafting alts fall too far behind I suppose. But I have to say that the core reason I played through Eregion up until I ran out of quests and had finished most of the deeds… was that it is not Moria.  As the fellowship did, so did I attempt to put off Moria until there was little other choice. The doors are open, darkness awaits It isn’t that I do not appreciate Moria for the epic setting that it is.  However, I have had more characters enter and never get to the far side than the fellowship.  I know I have made it to the far side with two, possibly three, characters.  But more have ended up abandoned at some quest hub deep under ground, loitering about hoping I will return to them. So I ran Eregion to the last quest, which got me about half way into level 53, with the hope of shortening my time passing through Moria.  I’ve been down there before, done all the sections, appreciated the zone, but this time around I am keen to move forward.  Of course, Mirkwood lays on the other side, and I know what a sleep inducing place that can be.  But I have to get through Moria first. I have made it through the first stage of the game, and the stable master map… something I had not seen before this run, and quite impressive it is… shows what points I have touched along the way. Eriador and surrounding regions Each highlighted dot is a stable master I have visited.  I have bypassed quite a bit… and might have to go back to some of them.  I cannot use the faction drops for the Mathom Society, Thorin’s Hall, or the Elves of Rivendell until I return and finish some prerequisite quests.    I can do that later though.  For now I press onward.
html:
As I have written here probably too many times at this point, my current run at Lord of the Rings Online is not focused on being completionist.  I do not need to do all the things.  I have even decided to be somewhat lax on the epic quest line.  The goal is to get to Mordor.

And then I hit Eregion, which is not a zone I have an affinity for generally… at least not at the level of Evendim or the Lone Lands.  It is a place… even a pretty place at times… but it isn’t exactly a distinctive place.  As a zone injected into the game to be the path between the original content and the first expansion, it can feel more than a little like past zones.

Riding across Eregion

At least there are not any bears there.  Birds, boars, wolves, lizards, half-orcs, various hillmen, and the Angmar choral society… and Redhorn goats, so many Redhorn goats… but bears… none that I have seen.  And, of course, the ruins of a past age.

Ruins, ruins, everywhere… also tents, because the half orcs have to sleep somewhere…

Everybody seems to be just camped out in one ruin or another.  That aligns, somewhat, with the books, the place being desolate and lacking any permanent habitation.  Of course, what doesn’t align with the books is you inability to toss a hobbit in any direction without them landing on the above list of wildlife.

There is even yet another escort quest where you shepherd Anurandir out of a heavily populated orc camp… which is, of course, based in some more ruins.

It is hardly a zone if there isn’t at least one quest like this…

I will say that at least Anurandir doesn’t mess about looking for his stick or his dad’s war surplus bayonet.  He heads on out of the area via the shortest possible path.

Anyway, despite all of that once I had hit level 50 and had my epic weapons… I kept on hanging around the place.

Part of it is that it is one of the zones where you do cross paths… if not directly, at least incidentally… with the fellowship on their journey eastward…. through the medium of discarded hobbit items.

It is a wonder Strider didn’t stuff them all in a sack…

You spend time trying to figure out where the fellowship went, what they had for lunch, and who left behind the latest bit of hobbit memorabilia.

Seriously, I saw a crying half-orc on the side of the road by this

So you follow the path of the fellowship through Hollin, up to the Redhorn Gate, then back around towards Moria… though, because the landscape must necessarily be condensed to a small enough area that it is easily traversable by players… the way the road from Buckland to Bree isn’t actually 75 miles in the game… makes it feel a bit like the fellowship was a an indolent pack of layabouts that could only manage half a mile at a time before collapsing in exhaustion.  I think you can literally see one of the camping spots from the next.

Eregion has a couple of other benefits.  It is, like some of my other favored zones, fairly quest rich in the traditional “vacuum up everything at the quest hub and go wild” sort of way.  I appreciate being able to go into the field to get a lot done in one pass.

Also, in the back half of the zone you end up collecting the next tier of resources.

Heavy, just how I like em

I am not crafting… but I am harvesting.  At least up until my transferred crafting alts fall too far behind I suppose.

But I have to say that the core reason I played through Eregion up until I ran out of quests and had finished most of the deeds… was that it is not Moria.  As the fellowship did, so did I attempt to put off Moria until there was little other choice.

The doors are open, darkness awaits

It isn’t that I do not appreciate Moria for the epic setting that it is.  However, I have had more characters enter and never get to the far side than the fellowship.  I know I have made it to the far side with two, possibly three, characters.  But more have ended up abandoned at some quest hub deep under ground, loitering about hoping I will return to them.

So I ran Eregion to the last quest, which got me about half way into level 53, with the hope of shortening my time passing through Moria.  I’ve been down there before, done all the sections, appreciated the zone, but this time around I am keen to move forward.  Of course, Mirkwood lays on the other side, and I know what a sleep inducing place that can be.  But I have to get through Moria first.

I have made it through the first stage of the game, and the stable master map… something I had not seen before this run, and quite impressive it is… shows what points I have touched along the way.

Eriador and surrounding regions

Each highlighted dot is a stable master I have visited.  I have bypassed quite a bit… and might have to go back to some of them.  I cannot use the faction drops for the Mathom Society, Thorin’s Hall, or the Elves of Rivendell until I return and finish some prerequisite quests.    I can do that later though.  For now I press onward.
